title: Psalms Chapter 121 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 121 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 121 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 121.

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:1, where does the speaker lift up his eyes?
questions.correctAnswer: Unto the hills
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:1 states, 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills, from whence cometh my help.'

questions.question: Who is the help that Psalms 121:2 says comes to the speaker?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:2 says, 'My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:3, what will not happen to the foot of the one kept by God?
questions.correctAnswer: It will not be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:3 states, 'He will not suffer thy foot to be moved.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 121:4 says that the one who keeps Israel will neither slumber nor sleep.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 says, 'Behold, he that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.'

questions.question: Who is described as the keeper and shade upon the right hand in Psalms 121:5?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:5 states, 'The LORD is thy keeper: the LORD is thy shade upon thy right hand.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:6, what shall not smite the speaker by day or night?
questions.correctAnswer: The sun and the moon
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:6 says, 'The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.'

questions.question: What does Psalms 121:7 say the LORD shall preserve the speaker from?
questions.correctAnswer: All evil
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:7 states, 'The LORD shall preserve thee from all evil.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 121:7 also says the LORD shall preserve the speaker's soul.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:7 says, 'he shall preserve thy soul.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:8, what shall the LORD preserve from this time forth and forevermore?
options: Thy going out and thy coming in
questions.correctAnswer: Thy going out and thy coming in
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:8 states, 'The LORD shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in from this time forth, and even for evermore.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 121:3 mentions that God who keeps you will slumber.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:3 says, 'He that keepeth thee will not slumber,' denying that God slumbers.

questions.question: What phrase completes this from Psalms 121:1? 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: hills
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:1 states, 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills.'

questions.question: Who made heaven and earth according to Psalms 121:2?
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:2 says, 'My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:5, what is the LORD to the speaker?
questions.correctAnswer: Thy keeper and thy shade
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:5 states, 'The LORD is thy keeper: the LORD is thy shade upon thy right hand.'

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 121:6: 'The sun shall not ______ thee by day, nor the moon by night.'
questions.correctAnswer: smite
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:6 states, 'The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.'

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:4, what two things will the keeper of Israel neither do?
questions.correctAnswer: Neither slumber nor sleep
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 says, 'Behold, he that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.'

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 121 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 121 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 121, what biblical truth would you share about God's help?
options: My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth.
My help cometh from my own strength and wisdom.
My help is from my friends and family.
My help is found in material possessions.
questions.correctAnswer: My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:2 teaches that our help comes from the LORD, the Creator of heaven and earth, reminding us to trust God's power rather than ourselves or others. This is supported by verses 1 and 3-4 which emphasize looking to God for help and His protective watchfulness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 121 instruct us to maintain faith and trust in God during daily life?
options: By lifting our eyes unto the hills, from where our help comes.
By relying on our own understanding and strength.
By ignoring challenges and hoping they go away.
questions.correctAnswer: By lifting our eyes unto the hills, from where our help comes.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:1 encourages us to look upward, symbolizing a focus on God who provides help, which fosters faith and trust, as also echoed in verses 2 and 5 regarding God's role as our keeper and protector.

questions.question: A family is concerned about safety when traveling. According to Psalms 121, what assurance can you give them?
options: The LORD shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in from this time forth, and even for evermore.
You should rely solely on your own caution and planning.
Travel is always risky and cannot be protected.
Only worldly security measures can keep you safe.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall preserve thy going out and thy coming in from this time forth, and even for evermore.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:8 promises that God preserves our movements continuously, providing comfort and assurance for travelers, reflecting His constant protection as stated also in verses 3 and 4.

questions.question: How does Psalms 121 teach about God's vigilance over His people?
options: He that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.
God rests and sometimes is unaware of our needs.
God only watches over some of His people.
God watches only during the daytime.
questions.correctAnswer: He that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 clearly states God's unceasing vigilance, emphasizing that He never sleeps or slumbers, showing His constant care, which is also reflected in verses 3 and 5 about His protection.

questions.question: What practical lesson about perseverance through trials is found in Psalms 121?
options: God will not suffer thy foot to be moved; He who keeps you does not slumber.
Trials mean God has abandoned you.
You must face trials alone without God's help.
questions.correctAnswer: God will not suffer thy foot to be moved; He who keeps you does not slumber.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:3 teaches that God protects and stabilizes us during trials, reinforcing perseverance through His watchful presence, also supported by verses 4 and 7 which emphasize His preservation and protection.

questions.question: According to Psalms 121, how should believers view God’s protection against daily hardships?
options: The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.
Hardships are caused by God’s punishment.
questions.correctAnswer: The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:6 assures believers that God protects them from harm both day and night, symbolizing His comprehensive care, which ties with verses 5 and 7 about God’s protective presence and preservation.

questions.question: How does Psalms 121 encourage believers to trust God in their spiritual walk?
options: The LORD shall preserve thy soul.
Believers must rely only on themselves.
Avoid trusting God for spiritual matters.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall preserve thy soul.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:7 highlights God's care for our soul, encouraging believers to trust Him for spiritual preservation as well as physical protection, in harmony with verses 3 and 8 about God’s safeguarding role.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 121, God sometimes sleeps and may miss our needs.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 clearly states that God neither slumbers nor sleeps, meaning He is always alert and attentive to our needs, supported by verses 3 and 5 emphasizing His constant watchfulness.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 121 teaches that God's protection is only temporary and limited to certain times.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:8 states God's preservation covers your going out and coming in from this time forth and even forevermore, indicating eternal and continuous protection, supported by verses 3 and 7 about ongoing care.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The LORD is thy keeper: the LORD is thy ______ upon thy right hand."
questions.correctAnswer: shade
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:5 states that the LORD is our keeper and shade upon the right hand, symbolizing His protective presence and comfort, underscoring God’s watchful care as also seen in verses 3 and 4.

questions.question: How can believers apply the teaching of Psalms 121 about God's constant vigilance to their prayer life?
options: Trust that God is always attentive to their prayers and never sleeps.
Only pray when they feel like it because God may not hear all prayers.
Prayers are unnecessary because God is indifferent.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust that God is always attentive to their prayers and never sleeps.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 and 3 emphasize that God never slumbers or sleeps and keeps watch over us, encouraging believers to pray with confidence in God's constant attentiveness, supported further by verses 5 and 7.

questions.question: What does Psalms 121 teach about God's role in protecting us from evil?
options: The LORD shall preserve thee from all evil.
We must protect ourselves without God’s help.
Evil is unavoidable and God does not intervene.
Only human effort can keep us from evil.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD shall preserve thee from all evil.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:7 clearly states God's promise to preserve us from all evil, encouraging reliance on His protection as confirmed in verses 3 and 8 about His safeguarding care.

questions.question: How can Psalms 121 help believers maintain contentment during uncertain times?
options: By trusting that the LORD is their keeper and protector always.
By focusing only on worldly success and security.
By worrying about every possible problem.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting that the LORD is their keeper and protector always.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:5 reassures believers that the LORD is their keeper and protector, which fosters contentment and peace, supported by verses 1 and 8 about God's continual help and preservation.

questions.question: When facing temptation, how does Psalms 121 encourage believers to respond?
options: Trust in God's constant preservation and protection.
Rely only on personal strength without God's help.
Give in to temptation as unavoidable.
Avoid seeking God's help during temptation.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God's constant preservation and protection.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:7 and 8 promise God's preservation from evil and protection in all circumstances, encouraging believers to rely on Him when facing temptation, in agreement with verses 3 and 4 about God's watchfulness.

questions.question: How does Psalms 121 guide believers in their work ethic and integrity?
options: By trusting God's protection as they diligently go about their tasks.
By relying on deceit to succeed.
By avoiding responsibility and hard work.
By seeking shortcuts without God’s guidance.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting God's protection as they diligently go about their tasks.
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:8 speaks of the LORD preserving your going out and coming in, which includes daily work and activities, encouraging believers to trust God’s protection while acting with integrity, supported by verses 3 and 5.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 121 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 121.

questions.question: In Psalms 121:2, who is identified as the source of help, and what is the significance of this identification in the context of ancient Near Eastern beliefs?
options: The LORD, who made heaven and earth
The mountains, as gods of strength
The sun, as a life-giving deity
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD, who made heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:2 states 'My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth,' emphasizing the monotheistic belief in Yahweh as Creator, contrasting with polytheistic mountain or sun gods in the ancient Near East.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Psalms 121:3-4 when stating 'He will not suffer thy foot to be moved' and 'he that keepeth Israel shall neither slumber nor sleep'?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism emphasizing God's vigilance
questions.explanation: Verses 3 and 4 use parallelism, a common Hebrew poetic device, to emphasize God's constant watchfulness over His people by repeating the idea that He neither slumbers nor sleeps.

questions.question: The phrase 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills' in Psalms 121:1 can be understood as an example of what ancient Near Eastern cultural practice?
options: Seeking divine help from natural landmarks
questions.correctAnswer: Seeking divine help from natural landmarks
questions.explanation: In ancient Near Eastern cultures, hills and mountains were often viewed as abodes of deities or sources of divine help; the psalmist’s lifting eyes to the hills reflects this cultural symbolism (Psalms 121:1).

questions.question: Which New Testament passage most closely echoes the theme of God’s protection as expressed in Psalms 121:7-8?
options: John 10:28-29, where Jesus speaks of eternal security
questions.correctAnswer: John 10:28-29, where Jesus speaks of eternal security
questions.explanation: John 10:28-29 reflects the theme of divine preservation and protection over believers’ lives, paralleling Psalms 121:7-8’s assurance of preservation from evil and continual care.

questions.question: The Hebrew term for 'keeper' in Psalms 121:5, which describes the LORD as 'thy keeper,' is closely connected to which Old Testament concept?
options: Shamar, meaning to guard or preserve
questions.correctAnswer: Shamar, meaning to guard or preserve
questions.explanation: The term 'keeper' (shomer) derives from the root shamar, a key Old Testament concept implying God's protective and preserving role over His people (Psalms 121:5).

questions.question: How does the theme of divine vigilance in Psalms 121:3-4 anticipate New Testament descriptions of Christ as the Good Shepherd?
options: Both emphasize unceasing watchfulness over the flock
Both focus on miraculous healing powers
Both highlight judgment of the wicked
Both describe the shepherd’s physical strength
questions.correctAnswer: Both emphasize unceasing watchfulness over the flock
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:3-4’s portrayal of God who neither slumbers nor sleeps anticipates Christ’s role as the Good Shepherd in John 10, who continually watches over His sheep.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 121:6, both the sun by day and the moon by night can cause harm to the one whom the LORD protects.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:6 explicitly states, 'The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night,' indicating divine protection from harm caused by these celestial bodies.

questions.question: Which structural feature characterizes Psalms 121 as a 'Song of degrees' and how does this relate to its use in ancient Israelite worship?
options: It is one of the fifteen ascending songs sung by pilgrims traveling to Jerusalem
It is a lament sung at the destruction of the temple
It is a royal psalm celebrating the king’s coronation
It is a wisdom psalm teaching about creation
questions.correctAnswer: It is one of the fifteen ascending songs sung by pilgrims traveling to Jerusalem
questions.explanation: 'Song of degrees' refers to a collection of fifteen psalms (120–134) sung during pilgrimages to Jerusalem, with Psalms 121 being one of them, emphasizing trust in divine protection during the journey (Psalms 121:1).

questions.question: What typological significance does the repeated assurance of preservation in Psalms 121:7-8 have in the broader biblical narrative?
options: It foreshadows the ultimate salvation and protection offered through Christ
It symbolizes the permanence of the Davidic monarchy
It prefigures the destruction of Jerusalem
It represents the cyclical nature of agricultural seasons
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the ultimate salvation and protection offered through Christ
questions.explanation: The promise that 'The LORD shall preserve thee' foreshadows New Testament themes of eternal security and salvation through Jesus Christ as ultimate protector (Psalms 121:7-8).

questions.question: The depiction of God as 'thy shade upon thy right hand' in Psalms 121:5 uses which literary device, and what is its significance in the ancient cultural context?
options: Simile comparing God to a sheltering cloud
Personification of the right hand as a guardian
questions.correctAnswer: Metaphor illustrating close protective presence
questions.explanation: Calling the LORD 'thy shade upon thy right hand' is a metaphor that conveys God's intimate protection, as shade provided relief and safety in the hot ancient Near Eastern environment (Psalms 121:5).

questions.question: In Psalms 121:8, the phrase 'from this time forth, and even for evermore' suggests what theological concept about God’s care?
options: The temporary nature of divine protection
The conditional blessings based on obedience
questions.correctAnswer: God’s eternal and unchanging guardianship
questions.explanation: The wording emphasizes the perpetual and everlasting nature of God's protective care over believers, indicating it is ongoing and unchanging (Psalms 121:8).

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern belief is challenged by the declaration in Psalms 121:2 that help comes from 'the LORD, which made heaven and earth'?
options: Ancestor worship as the main divine source
Animism attributing spirits to natural features
Astrology as the dominant divine influence
questions.correctAnswer: Polytheism with multiple creator gods
questions.explanation: By declaring Yahweh as the sole creator of heaven and earth, Psalms 121:2 rejects polytheistic views common in the ancient Near East, affirming monotheism.

questions.question: How does the motif of God’s sleepless watchfulness in Psalms 121 relate to the broader biblical theme of divine omniscience and care?
options: It emphasizes God’s constant vigilance and care without fatigue
It suggests God’s inability to rest until justice is done
It communicates God’s impatience with human weakness
It implies that God’s power is limited to daytime only
questions.correctAnswer: It emphasizes God’s constant vigilance and care without fatigue
questions.explanation: The motif of God not slumbering or sleeping (Psalms 121:3-4) symbolizes His omniscience and tireless protection over His people, a recurring biblical theme.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Psalms 121:1 begins with 'A Song of degrees. I will lift up mine eyes unto the _____, from whence cometh my help.'
questions.correctAnswer: hills
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly states 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills,' indicating the psalmist looks toward the hills as symbolic sources of help (Psalms 121:1).

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 121 presents God as a passive observer who occasionally intervenes in human affairs.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: The psalm depicts God as an active, vigilant protector who neither slumbers nor sleeps and preserves His people continually (Psalms 121:3-8).

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 121 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 121 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:2, from where does the psalmist declare his help comes?
options: From the LORD, who made heaven and earth
questions.correctAnswer: From the LORD, who made heaven and earth
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:2 states that help comes from the LORD, the creator of heaven and earth. This affirms God's role as sovereign Creator and reliable helper, consistent with passages like Isaiah 41:10, Deuteronomy 33:27, Hebrews 13:6, and John 14:27.

questions.question: What does Psalms 121:3 teach about God's protection over the believer's steps?
options: God allows the believer to stumble to teach humility
God will not suffer thy foot to be moved; He who keeps you does not slumber
God's protection depends on human effort
questions.correctAnswer: God will not suffer thy foot to be moved; He who keeps you does not slumber
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:3 emphasizes God's vigilant protection, assuring that He will not allow the believer to stumble and that He is ever-watchful. This aligns with 1 Peter 5:7, Proverbs 3:23-24, Isaiah 40:11, and Hebrews 4:13.

questions.question: Who is described as neither slumbering nor sleeping in Psalms 121:4?
questions.correctAnswer: He that keeps Israel
questions.explanation: Psalms 121:4 identifies God as the one who keeps Israel and neither slumbers nor sleeps, highlighting God's constant vigilance. This truth is echoed in 1 Thessalonians 5:23, Psalm 34:15, Jeremiah 31:3, and Romans 8:38-39.

questions.question: In Psalms 121:5, how is the LORD described in relation to the believer?
options: The LORD is a distant judge
The LORD is thy keeper and shade upon thy right hand
The LORD is a silent observer
The LORD is a passing stranger
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is thy keeper and shade upon thy right hand
questions.explanation: This verse portrays the LORD as a personal guardian and protector, providing shelter and defense, analogous to the shade on the right hand. Similar protective imagery appears in Exodus 33:22, Psalm 91:1-4, Isaiah 49:2, and John 10:27-29.

questions.question: What does Psalms 121:6 promise regarding harm from the sun and moon?
options: The sun and moon shall scorch and blind the believer
The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night
The sun and moon will only harm the wicked
The believer must avoid the sun and moon
questions.correctAnswer: The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night
questions.explanation: The verse assures that God's protection extends to all times, preventing harm from natural elements, symbolizing comprehensive divine care. This corresponds with Job 5:20, Isaiah 54:10, Matthew 5:45, and Revelation 7:16.

questions.question: According to Psalms 121:7, from what does the LORD preserve the believer?
options: From all evil and the soul's peril
questions.correctAnswer: From all evil and the soul's peril
questions.explanation: The LORD's preservation is comprehensive, encompassing all evil and safeguarding the soul, indicating spiritual as well as physical protection. This theme is reflected in 2 Thessalonians 3:3, John 17:15, Psalm 23:4, and Romans 8:28.

questions.question: What continuous protection is promised in Psalms 121:8?
options: Preservation in all comings and goings from now and forevermore
Protection only in times of war
questions.correctAnswer: Preservation in all comings and goings from now and forevermore
questions.explanation: This verse assures God's unending protection over the believer's daily life and future, reflecting eternal security. Related scriptures include John 10:28, Psalm 91:11, Isaiah 43:2, and Philippians 1:6.

questions.question: The phrase 'I will lift up mine eyes unto the hills' in Psalms 121:1 symbolically points to what theological truth?
options: Looking to God as the source of help
questions.correctAnswer: Looking to God as the source of help
questions.explanation: The hills symbolize places of divine presence or power, and lifting eyes to them signifies seeking divine aid, consistent with Exodus 15:2, Isaiah 40:31, Hebrews 12:2, and Psalm 46:1.

questions.question: What attribute of God is most prominently revealed through His never slumbering or sleeping, as seen in Psalms 121:3-4?
questions.correctAnswer: Omniscience
questions.explanation: God's unceasing watchfulness indicates His perfect knowledge and awareness, a facet of omniscience, as also shown in Psalm 139:1-4, Proverbs 15:3, Isaiah 27:3, and 1 John 3:20.

questions.question: In Psalms 121:5, the LORD is described as 'thy shade upon thy right hand.' This metaphor communicates which aspect of God's character?
questions.correctAnswer: God's protection and nearness
questions.explanation: Shade provides relief and shelter; being at the right hand connotes closeness and favor, revealing God's protective and intimate care. This imagery resonates with Exodus 15:6, Psalm 16:8, Isaiah 25:4, and Romans 8:31-34.

questions.question: How does Psalms 121:6's promise that 'The sun shall not smite thee by day, nor the moon by night' relate to biblical eschatology?
options: It anticipates the removal of cosmic judgment
It predicts the destruction of the sun and moon
It refers only to ordinary daily protection
questions.correctAnswer: It anticipates the removal of cosmic judgment
questions.explanation: The protection from sun and moon can symbolize deliverance from cosmic troubles, a theme developed in eschatological passages like Isaiah 30:26, Revelation 21:23, Matthew 24:29, and Joel 2:31, pointing to God's ultimate care in the new creation.

questions.question: What theological concept is illuminated by the LORD's preservation of 'thy going out and thy coming in' in Psalms 121:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Eternal security and providential care
questions.explanation: This phrase expresses God's ongoing, sovereign oversight of all aspects of the believer's life, emphasizing divine providence and security, supported by Psalm 139:8, Proverbs 16:9, John 10:28-29, and Romans 8:38-39.

questions.question: Which Christological truth can be inferred from Psalms 121:2 stating 'My help cometh from the LORD, which made heaven and earth'?
options: Christ as Creator and eternal Helper
Christ as merely a human teacher
questions.correctAnswer: Christ as Creator and eternal Helper
questions.explanation: Since Jesus is identified in the New Testament as Creator (John 1:3, Colossians 1:16) and Helper (John 14:16-17), this verse anticipates Christ's divine nature and role in salvation history, consistent with Hebrews 1:3 and Isaiah 9:6.

questions.question: Which doctrine about God's nature is emphasized by the fact that He neither slumbers nor sleeps (Psalms 121:4)?
questions.correctAnswer: God's immutability and aseity
questions.explanation: God's unchanging nature and self-existence are highlighted by His ceaseless watchfulness, as supported by Malachi 3:6, James 1:17, Exodus 3:14, and Psalm 90:2.

questions.question: What systematic theological theme does the preservation of 'thy soul' in Psalms 121:7 suggest?
options: The doctrine of sanctification and God's sustaining grace
questions.correctAnswer: The doctrine of sanctification and God's sustaining grace
questions.explanation: God's preservation of the soul implies ongoing spiritual sustaining, sanctifying the believer, supported by Philippians 1:6, Jude 1:24, 1 Thessalonians 5:23, and John 10:28-29.
